initial_comment.comment: Hi All, this file contains the protobuf messages and the relative flow with the security checks to put in place. This a joint effort with <@U1BC5A0F9> and <@U26T99AQ4>.

<@U0XV1HDL3|cca> has joined the channel
Request from <@U0XPR4NP4> to accommodate simpler types of transactions that contain either reconfiguration requests, or simply hashes of transactions.
Reconfiguration may concern either the fabric-network (endorsers) or the ordering service.
<@U1QUW6W82|michele> has joined the channel

<@U1BC5A0F9>, on page 11, it shows that the proposal form the SDK has an entry for chaincode simulation but if this comes form the SDK it’s going to be hard to have the SDK perform the simulation. Wouldn’t relying on the simulation information back from the endorsers be enough? the client has always the option of not submitting the transaction if things are different than expected...
So, this is actually an optional field

that is the client would send to the peer (the first peer he contacts) a proposal that does not contain simulation result. Then that peer will compute simulation result based on his state info and return a response to the client, that the latter will use in the proposals to the rest of endorsers.
understood
we need to be careful that the other proposals may have a hash different from the first one I guess
<@U1BC5A0F9> <@U0ULK2JPP> Can we talk and nail down some changes to the transaction format?
If you could send us the proto (non-pdf) <@U0ULK2JPP> and I could do the proposed changes and send back so that we can discuss

thanks!
on a side note: has anyone investigated the overhead of splitting serialization and deserialization in multiple substructures as opposed to a single bigger structure?

for example proposal has a header and a payload that are serialized separately, is there significant performance penalty (or advantage) to doing this as opposed to serializing one data structure that contains both?
It’s much cleaner than the previous one :slightly_smiling_face:
you did not remove the fabric_next.proto etc in the parent dir though
<@U0KQ9QKH6|pmullaney> has joined the channel

<@U1QUW6W82> I'm not sure if you're aware (it was news to me not so long ago), but protobuf structures do not serialize deterministically, so a signature cannot be over an unmarshaled struct, as two users might serializes it to different bytes and correspondingly verify or not verify the signature.  I think that is why there is so much embedding of marshaled objects, or, maybe you're spotting something else?  I know <@U0XR6J961> was pushing for us to switch to ASN1 for things which we sign over, though its encoding is noticeably slower than protobuf.
